Summary I design and develop data interfaces, and I've specialized in data visualization for over 9 years. 
 
Feel free to reach out to me if you're looking for help designing around data. 
 
I love to create tools that help people understand complex data. My favorite projects are those that help users see something in a novel way, and even better, when what they see helps them improve their lives. 
 
I'm a generalist, with experience in design, programming, and research. I seek out challenges that reach across different fields and require a healthy struggle to find a good solution. I strive to constantly learn new things and in turn teach others. 
 
I believe that understanding the user's needs is THE way to start designing any product. Summary I design and develop data interfaces, and I've specialized in data visualization for over 9 years.

Experience Statistician Stanford University School of Medicine October 2012  – Present (2 years 11 months) Surgery Department I serve as the data analysis resource for the faculty and resident surgeons in the department. Project areas include effectiveness of surgical diagnostic imaging devices, teaching methods for training medical residents, associations between hospital and surgeon procedure volumes with clinical outcomes, and associations between nurse-to-patient ratios and adverse events. Several projects have been presented at conferences, and more abstracts and manuscripts are in progress. Many projects use large national- and state-level Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project (HCUP) data sets.  
 
I perform analyses in both R and SAS, using SQL to merge and manipulate data. I write reusable functions and macros for data manipulation, model building, and results table formatting. I create clearly written and illustrated reports of analyses and results for non-technical collaborators, and produce statistical analysis and results sections, tables, and figures for abstracts, posters, journal articles. I provide power vs. sample size curves for study planning, and I contribute statistical content to grant proposals. Biostatistician/Bioinformatician Aviir, Inc. September 2010  –  December 2011  (1 year 4 months) My contributions included planning and implementing data analyses for biochemical assay calibration/quality control and large-cohort clinical model validation. I was very productive in building extendable, reusable R codebases for our projects. I cleaned, modularized, and substantially extended previously written code. For a newly added source of lab data, I built from scratch a data cleaning and processing pipeline that included format standardization, data entry error checks, outlier detection, measurement calibration, and process diagnostic graphs. In doing so, I accomodated frequently changing input formats, and implemented custom quality control and calibration procedures that I helped plan, evaluate, and revise.  
 
I communicated regularly, clearly, and efficiently with my colleagues to coordinate our efforts and answer their questions about our statistical results, and I regularly prepared and gave presentations to the entire R&D team during weekly update meetings. I also contributed to statistical methods sections for operating procedures and technical reports. I continue to consult for Aviir often. Summary I combine an engineer's affinity for order and efficiency with an info nerd's desire to squeeze juicy meaning from the obscuring pulp of tree-ripened data. I am comfortable with questionable metaphors. I care about people and want to make the a world better place. I have a broad interest in pulling data together, extracting meaning from it and communicating that meaning to audiences with diverse levels of expertise. I prefer creating answers with utility rather than answers of convenience and strive to make my work relevant to the real world.
